1032741872546897920.text:
It's still early days for SourceCred - I don't recommend allocating any tokens based on cred just yet.  It's early days for crypto too - like the internet in 95, we need to build some more infra to get ready for prime time.

And like the internet, prime time is gonna be big.

1032741871498326016.text: You can read more about it at http://sourcecred.io , or check out the prototype, which shows SourceCred's own cred: http://sourcecred.io/prototype/ . You can also try the prototype on any project you find interesting - instructions on GitHub.

1032741870416191488.text: SourceCred's mission is to create a fair, transparent, and robust system for attributing "cred" in a project to its contributors. Cred will be computed based on GitHub interactions, source code analysis, human feedback, and more.

1032741869443153920.text: But before that is possible, we need a system for allocating a project's grain to it's contributors. It needs to be fair, transparent, and produce good incentives, so that people earn grain by helping the project, not by gaming the algorithm. That's where @sourcecred comes in.

1032741868440772608.text: That's the vision for "grain", a system of tokens that act as economic scaffolding for open-source projects. Grain will be to open-source projects as equity is to corporations.

1032741867027230721.text: What if the value of these tokens was correlated with the long-term success and usefulness of the project, so that an ecosystem of "venture socialists" would emerge to fund promising early-stage open-source projects?

1032741866205134848.text: What if those tokens flowed according to the code dependency graph, so that developers and early supporters of foundational technologies like Git or @babeljs could become appropriately (i.e. fantastically) rewarded?

1032741865349476352.text: What if every OS project could make its own project-specific token, and distribute them to the project's contributors? What if supporters who bought the token were rewarded with prioritized support, bugfixes, and influence on the feature roadmap?

1032741864351232000.text: We need a new go-to image for open-source sustainability. We need to fairly reward people who contribute to open-source projects. Luckily, crypto is all about giving us new ways to distribute value.

1032741863134920704.text: But switching drug discovery and medical tech to open-source seems a little far-fetched, because we do a bad job of rewarding open-source contributors. People build incredibly important core infra for the internet, then need to beg for donations. Crazy!https://twitter.com/mikeal/status/1030562739117158400 …

1032741862027669504.text: That's why Linux crushed Windows in the server market, and why market leaders like Google open-source crown jewel technologies like TensorFlow, rather than keeping them as proprietary advantages. It's the start of a new reality.

1032741860995825664.text: Keeping technology locked in a particular corporate citadel, with rules that stop others from hacking on it, improving it, and recombining it: *so* 20th century. In a networked age of rapid innovation, it's laughably inefficient.

1032741860064747520.text: This open-source economy is a fundamentally better fit for an economy driven by the spillovers & synergies of intangible capital. Corporations were a good mechanism for organizing & controlling 20th century value chains. Today, open-source is the best way to develop technology.

1032741859087462400.text: My take: in the future, most research & development will be open-source: anyone can use for free, and hack + contribute + improve. This will be huge. Imagine if drug discovery and medical technology went open source! Goodbye healthcare cost crisis.

1032741857648828416.text: Like the internet, this will enable many innovations. Some are obvious - like that email would eventually replace snail mail, or that bitcoin will eventually replace ACH. But many are non-obvious (who saw Wikipedia coming?), and those are the ones I'm most excited for.

1032741856637935616.text: This is analogous to how before the internet, you couldn't just distribute a video to the world. CBS could, but you couldn't. Now it's just a simple matter of uploading to YouTube.

1032741855681630208.text: One specific instance, courtesy of @michael_nielsen: before crypto, you couldn't just create a new market. Goldman Sachs could, but you couldn't. Now it's just a little bit of coding to make an ERC20 token and you can get it listed on a decentralized exchange.

1032741854817611776.text:
Crypto fundamentally changes the economics of value distribution. It also makes things 10x cheaper:
- exchanging value pairwise (bitcoin)
- collaborating on shared value (smart contracts, creating new markets)
- distributing value en masse (ICOs, airdrops)

1032741853894828032.text:
The internet fundamentally changed the economics of information distribution, making many things >10x cheaper:
- exchanging information pairwise (email, facetime)
- collaborating on shared information (wikis, reddit, github)
- distributing information en masse (netflix, twitter)

1031473595464073217.text:
Thought provoking article on a movement to give legal rights to rivers. If corporations are people, why not rivers too?

https://e360.yale.edu/features/should-rivers-have-rights-a-growing-movement-says-its-about-time …

1031416313619468288.text:
There are two kinds of disruptive innovation:

10->1: something becomes much cheaper. Like email vs snail mail.
0->1: A fundamentally new capability. Like wikipedia.

The internet brought both kinds. What about crypto?

Common computing: "our computer". Crypto-enabled platforms based on common ownership and agreed rules.

Fuck the cloud. #ipfs #truebit

1008574191124168706.text: 6. We've also been having more conversation going in our Discord - discussing how to get the incentives right so we reward development and not gaming the system; how not to mess with working social dynamics, etc. Feel free to join the convo!https://discordapp.com/invite/tsBTgc9

1008574190419566592.text:
5. Once we finish the graph re-write, we're planning to:
- make the cred attribution tunable, by setting prior weights on node and edge types
- make the cred attribution improvable, by adding the 'spotlight' plugin for directing cred towards important contributions

1008574189614198784.text: 4. We're just polishing that up now. It's taken a few weeks to get right, but I'm proud that we are taking our time to make sure SourceCred is built on a good foundation. Since SourceCred will be distributed & involve many plugins, giant monolith data structure = bad.

1008574188888571904.text: 3. We decided to pay down this technical debt early, and re-write our core abstraction. We stopped storing arbitrary data in the graph. Now plugins (like the Git & GitHub plugins) store connections in the graph, but bring their own data stores for other info.

1008574188179738624.text: 2. Having de-risked one of our core technical challenges, we took a step back to refactor the architecture. At the start, we put all data - Git metadata, GitHub issue text, etc - into one data structure: the Graph. This proved unwieldy, and would make SourceCred hard to scale.

1008574187428966400.text: 1. @wchargin and built a new prototype, which ingests data from GitHub  and Git into a large graph and runs PageRank on it. We wanted to check that we can scale in-browser PageRank to graphs with >100k nodes. The answer: we can! It's even quite fast.

1008574186225168389.text: Since leaving Google / TensorBoard, I've been working on #sourcecred. SourceCred's goal is to recognize open-source developers and maintainers by assigning 'cred' to their contributions. Here's a development update from the past month.

998353822413086721.text: Thus, Twitter embodies a much richer data structure - a graph instead of a counter. The richer data structure affords higher quality data processing, and robustness to sibyls

998353482280091648.text: Crypto twitter does a much better job of filtering noise than crypto reddit. I think a key difference is that Reddit's content filtering is just about counting numbers of upvotes, whereas Twitter is about relationships between people and decisions by people to retweet each other

996435849758756864.text:
key question for technologists: 

what groups does your technology differentially empower? 

Why is it better at empowering good than bad? 

Just focusing on the good things that could happen is naive and dangerous.

996435485051371520.text:
Modern AI/ML is massively empowering to the surveillance state. Today they just record all your convos, tomorrow they’ll listen to and interpret them. 

People don’t talk about this much bc general paperclip/terminator AI safety dominates the debate.

996265529978507264.text: We like the way flowers look and smell because we our sense of aesthetic is similar to that of the flowers’ true target audience: bugs

Credit attribution

Project-specific cryptoassets

Open-source devs get paid

988812910557253632.text: mad crypto experiment: meme coin. Every day, meme coin is awarded to the creators of the most-upvoted memes about meme coin. Upvoting a meme requires staking memecoin, which prevents sibyls and provides some reason to hold memecoin.

In the future, video games are indistinguishable from reality, and even simulate the fear of death. 
As a result, back in the real world, there’s a growing epidemic of reckless deaths and violence by ppl who were wholly desensitized.

979453815152758785.text: here's another opinion which is maybe more controversial: once crypto creates rewards for building open projects, video game industry will be revolutionized. closed-source approaches wont compete w/ the amount of amazing talent + enthusiasm available by opening development

979453370766209024.text: finally, me (sourcecred), "evocative" opinion: money today is based on thousands-year-old math,  crypto's ambition should be greater: creating that which is to money as vector calculus is to scalar arithmetic. able to represent many different kinds of value, with gradients.

979452637400543232.text:
from @Iiterature (@a16z): vision of decentralization that we're pushing won't scale to mainstream, because the distribution of value is too skewed to early adopters.
(this resonated with me - generating enormous returns for early adopters is problematic / more inequality)

979452636503011328.text: from @ericsson_axel (@1protocolinc):  adverse selection effect among crypto projects targetting a common meme, like "banking the unbanked". obvious, common goal implies they may not be thinking deeply about the space

979439828860207104.text:
from @JTremback (@Altheamesh): It's not proven yet whether decentralized tech can be more efficient / cost effective than centralized. Prices on AWS, etc may be persistently lower
(my 2c: if "cost" is more than just price, but also friction, etc, decentratech may win there)

979438974618890240.text: from @ljxie (@scalarcapital) not sure about algorithmic stablecoins - if an entity with name-brand trust and recognition among consumers, like Fidelity, entered the space, they could clean up. (aware of TrustToken / TrueUSD - but they don't yet have brand power.)

979433633856368640.text: from @mhluongo (@keep_project): proof of stake and its trust in "skin in the game" is a nice idea, but still unproven. not certain it will work until we see it successfully deployed.

979433632648503296.text: from @jessewldn (@a16z): we pay a lot of attention to technical details and the protocol, but the value may accrue based on softer human things like identity, values, and brand appeal

979432657158209536.text:
from @z1awrence (@1protocolinc): too much emphasis on making smart contracting languages dev-friendly & familiar. we need to focus on security and correctness first. 
(my note: i'm skeptical this will happen, see Worse is Better: https://www.jwz.org/doc/worse-is-better.html … … js is a virus)

979431831576633344.text: from @AriannaSimpson (Autonomous Partners): in today's crypto environment, it's easy to make money, but hard not to die. 5 years out, the winners will be the ones that successfully weathered potential catastrophes, like hacks or redemptions / forced liquidation in bear markets

979431830645436416.text: from @ali01 (a16z): every piece of crypto-infrastructure will wind up being commoditized. "economic routers" will sit one layer above and route away from platforms that have excess pricing power or profits

979431459705384960.text: attended a crypto dinner hosted by @a16z /@ali01 last night. Ali asked everyone for one controversial opinion. here are my notes! (opinions ethically published with consent from attendees )

978768032418840582.text: Airline ticket pricing makes so little sense. I want to change my TLV->JFK->SFO flight to be TLV->JFK->DTW->SFO. 2 ppl. If I throw away my JFK->SFO ticket and just buy JFK->DTW->SFO it costs $700. If I rebook thru delta? $6275. OMG->WTF

977009015187152898.text: I think open source is crypto’s coal mine. Hugely valuable to society, but very poorly recognized by financial system. Digital native, so much easier to measure and incentivize with cryptoeconomics. How about cryptoassets that precisely reward OS contributions? #sourcecred

977008352952696832.text: Trying to use crypto today as money replacement is like pushing trains as passenger transport in 1810. Hard to compete with incumbent practices. Need to find the “coal mine” of crypto - digital native domain that is already valuable, but poorly served by existing economic systems

977007539094134784.text: Steam engine & train are defining techs of industrial rev. At start, tho, not many applications - too immature. First use case? Mining & distributing coal. Coal needed for heating, but perfect fit for steam engine & train bc they were raw inputs to those techs
